Judge orders Foxborough to allow Kraft rep at meeting

A federal judge's ruling today follows a civil rights suit filed by the company owned by Robert Kraft alleging his representatives have repeatedly been denied the right to speak at open public meetings. (Globe, 2:44 p.m.)
  • 3/26 Foxborough, Krafts battle over billboards

Menino fires a broadside at city teachers

The inability of Boston's teachers' union to reach a new contract is keeping students from the right teachers, Mayor Thomas Menino said today. (Globe, 1:10 p.m.)

Bill Brett's party scene meets 'Mad Men'

"Mad Men" fans took to the restaurant Scollay Square in Boston over the weekend for a '60s night celebration in honor of the hit show's season five premiere.
  • Pictures Spotted in Boston: Out and about in the city

High court weighs individual mandate

Conservative justices sharply questioned the key component of President Obama's health care overhaul that requires people to buy insurance. (Globe, 1:17 p.m.)
  • Audio Listen to today's oral arguments in the case
  • Live blog Updates from hearings; share your thoughts
  • Key players  |  Demonstrators gather outside court
  • Discuss Is it constitutional? | Pictures Scenes from DC

Obama’s uncle has drunken driving charge continued without a finding

Onyango Obama, the uncle of President Obama, had his drunken driving case continued without a finding for one year today during a brief hearing. (Globe, 12:45 p.m.)
  • 8/30/11 Obama's uncle arrested in Framingham

Hyde Park residents get
their rightful ZIP code

A section on the neighborhood’s border won a battle with the US Postal Service to establish that they are, in fact, in Hyde Park, not in Mattapan.

Disabled veterans hit the ice

Sled hockey and other sports for the disabled have become popular with wounded veterans, requiring them to think, react, and move in new ways.

Seaport adding innovation center

Mayor Menino will unveil plans for a $5.5 million center in the Seaport District, part of a broader effort to transform the area into a hotbed of entrepreneurship.
boston capital | steven syre

The MBTA’s big debt problem

The MBTA will never break free from an annual cycle of fiscal contortions to balance its books without some commitment to reduce the overall debt.
opinion | Kevin Cullen

Cutting corners at National Grid

Union workers say the company wants to replace them with lower-paid workers with less training and experience, raising its profits while reducing its safety.

A123 to spend $55m to fix batteries

Fixing this latest defect could hurt the Waltham battery maker, which recently had millions of dollars in orders canceled by one of its biggest customers.

The art of self-expression

With help from local service agencies, expressive artists with mental and physical limitations have been able to move beyond their challenges.

Can chocolate help weight loss?

A new study says yes, it can. The study found that frequent chocolate eaters tend to weigh less than those who don’t indulge.

Business

Most home prices fell in January

Prices fell in 17 of the 20 largest US cities in January compared to the same month in 2011. That suggests the housing market remains weak, despite the best winter for home sales in five years.

Budget getaways in New England

Spring is the best in New England for finding travel bargains. Stuck between ski and beach seasons, hotels tend to slash their rates and restaurants start creatively filling up their specials boards.
